title: The Crucifixion of Jesus
shortSummary: John 19 details the suffering, crucifixion, death, and burial of Jesus Christ. This chapter highlights the fulfillment of Old Testament prophecies and the sacrificial nature of Jesus’ death for the salvation of humanity. It reveals the injustice He endured and His obedience to the Father’s will.
timeline: c. AD 30 - The Passion Week, specifically the day of Jesus’ crucifixion

keyCharacters.name: Pontius Pilate
keyCharacters.description: The Roman governor who presides over Jesus’ trial and authorizes His crucifixion despite finding no fault in Him.

keyCharacters.name: Jesus Christ
keyCharacters.description: The Son of God who is scourged, mocked, crucified, and dies to fulfill Scripture and provide salvation.

keyCharacters.name: Mary, mother of Jesus
keyCharacters.description: Stands near the cross witnessing her Son’s suffering and is entrusted to the beloved disciple’s care.

keyCharacters.name: Joseph of Arimathaea
keyCharacters.description: A secret disciple of Jesus who requests Pilate for Jesus’ body and provides His burial place.

keyCharacters.name: Nicodemus
keyCharacters.description: A Pharisee who assists Joseph of Arimathaea in preparing Jesus’ body for burial with spices.

definitions.definition: To be whipped or flogged as a form of punishment, causing severe physical pain and injury.
The Aramaic name for the place called the Pavement, where Pilate sat to judge Jesus.
A plant used in Jewish purification rituals; here it is used to lift the sponge with vinegar to Jesus’ mouth.
The day before the Sabbath, when Jews prepared for the Sabbath by completing necessary work, including burial.

outline.heading: Jesus is Scourged and Mocked
outline.description: Pilate orders Jesus to be scourged; soldiers mock Him with a crown of thorns and a purple robe, presenting Him as 'King of the Jews' to the crowd, highlighting His suffering and humiliation.

outline.heading: Pilate’s Judgment and the Crowd’s Demand
outline.description: Despite Pilate’s declaration of Jesus’ innocence, the Jewish leaders insist on crucifixion, accusing Jesus of claiming to be the Son of God and a king opposing Caesar.

outline.heading: The Crucifixion and Title on the Cross
outline.description: Jesus carries His cross to Golgotha and is crucified between two criminals; Pilate’s inscription 'Jesus of Nazareth the King of the Jews' fulfills prophecy and provokes opposition from Jewish leaders.

outline.heading: Jesus’ Mother and the Beloved Disciple
outline.description: Jesus entrusts the care of His mother to the beloved disciple, demonstrating His concern for family even in His final moments.

outline.heading: Jesus’ Death and Fulfillment of Scripture
outline.description: Jesus declares 'It is finished,' dies, and fulfills multiple Old Testament prophecies including that none of His bones would be broken and that He would be pierced.

outline.heading: Jesus’ Burial
outline.description: Joseph of Arimathaea and Nicodemus prepare Jesus’ body with spices and linen and lay Him in a new tomb near the place of crucifixion, completing the burial before the Sabbath.

application: Trust in Jesus’ obedience and sacrifice as the perfect fulfillment of God’s plan for salvation, even when facing trials and suffering.
Demonstrate care and responsibility for others, especially in times of hardship, as Jesus entrusted His mother to the beloved disciple.
Recognize the authority of God over earthly powers, understanding that all authority is ultimately given from above as Jesus taught Pilate.
Hold fast to the truth of Scripture’s fulfillment in Jesus’ life and death, strengthening faith in God’s promises.

keyVerses.text: Jesus answered, Thou couldest have no power at all against me, except it were given thee from above: therefore he that delivered me unto thee hath the greater sin.
keyVerses.significance: This verse affirms God’s sovereign control over earthly authorities and highlights the divine purpose in Jesus’ suffering.

keyVerses.text: When Jesus therefore had received the vinegar, he said, It is finished: and he bowed his head, and gave up the ghost.
keyVerses.significance: Jesus declares the completion of His redemptive work, signaling the fulfillment of salvation through His death.

keyVerses.text: For these things were done, that the scripture should be fulfilled, A bone of him shall not be broken.
keyVerses.significance: This verse emphasizes the fulfillment of Messianic prophecy, confirming Jesus as the promised Savior.

keyVerses.text: When Jesus therefore saw his mother, and the disciple standing by, whom he loved, he saith unto his mother, Woman, behold thy son! Then saith he to the disciple, Behold thy mother! And from that hour that disciple took her unto his own home.
keyVerses.significance: These verses show Jesus’ care for His family and the establishment of new spiritual relationships even in His final moments.
